G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing judgment regarding custody and parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applied to custody and parenting-time provisions), and personal jurisdiction over both parties.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Court is empowered to adjust midweek overnights, transportation responsibilities, and weekend schedules to minimize disruption to the child’s schooling and well‑being, so long as both parents retain the opportunity for a continuing relationship with their child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184; *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981).

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and controlling case law. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370–72 (1981) (modification requires material change of circumstances); *Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156, 159–60 (2001).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that, to obtain modification of a judgment for alimony or child support under Massachusetts law, the moving party must show a material change of circumstances since the earlier judgment. Although Schuler is an alimony/child support case rather than a custody case, it is routinely cited for the general ‘material change of circumstances’ standard applicable to modification proceedings under G.L. c. 208, including § 28. Thus, citing Schuler for the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances is accurate.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952).”

*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and controlling case law. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370–72 (1981) (modification requires material change of circumstances); *Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156, 159–60 (2001).
*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Pearson v. Pearson does not itself discuss or apply the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The Appeals Court expressly states that, because the husband did not challenge the modification, it would assume without deciding that the standards for modification were met and would address only the amount of child support. Thus, Pearson is not authority for the existence or content of the material-change requirement; Schuler is the proper citation for that proposition.
*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Because the former husband does not challenge the modification, we assume (without deciding) the standards for modification were met, and do not reach the question of how much deference should have been accorded to the parties’ child support agreement. The narrow question before us is whether the judge erred with respect to the amount of child support ordered. The statute governing support modification requires an analysis of both the changed circumstances of the parties and the best interests of the children. See G. L. c. 208, § 28.”

*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677,.proposition: The Father’s move and the resulting impact on the child’s school days constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances that was not contemplated by the Court at the time of the 2019 Judgment. See *Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 681–82 (2016) (relocation and resulting effects may constitute material change warranting modification); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. *Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677,.support_reasoning: Rosen v. Rosen is about whether courts may apply equitable credits against child support arrearages without violating the prohibition on retroactive modification in G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a). It does not address relocation, parenting schedules, school-day impacts, or what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification of custody or parenting time. Citing Rosen for the proposition that a parent’s move and its effect on school days is a material change is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677,.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.” (90 Mass. App. Ct. at 688).

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Father’s move and the resulting impact on the child’s school days constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances that was not contemplated by the Court at the time of the 2019 Judgment. See *Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 681–82 (2016) (relocation and resulting effects may constitute material change warranting modification); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Rosenthal holds that a request to modify custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the relocation itself. The court explicitly rejects treating the custodial parent’s relocation (and the resulting court‑ordered interim change in the child’s weekday residence and school) as the qualifying material change. Thus, Rosenthal is authority against using a parent’s move and its impact on school days, standing alone, as the material change justifying modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The probate judge found… 'Because Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro… most of his activities take place there.' This was a change in Caleb’s living arrangements brought about solely as a consequence of the mother’s compliance with the August 25 order… cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted."

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The current midweek schedule no longer serves the minor child’s best interests and is contrary to the public policy of promoting a stable, healthy, and predictable environment for children of separated parents. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985) (best interests of the child are paramount); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842–43 (2003).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas concerns removal of children from Massachusetts and articulates that removal must be in the child’s best interests and that those interests are intertwined with the custodial parent’s well‑being. It does not discuss or establish any principle about a ‘current midweek schedule,’ parenting-time schedules, or public policy favoring a specific type of stable or predictable visitation arrangement. While Yannas does say the child’s best interests are paramount, it does so in the specific context of relocation, not midweek scheduling, so using it to support that more specific proposition is overbroad.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
“The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

“Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u2.proposition: The current midweek schedule no longer serves the minor child’s best interests and is contrary to the public policy of promoting a stable, healthy, and predictable environment for children of separated parents. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985) (best interests of the child are paramount); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842–43 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u2.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Custody of Kali does emphasize that the best interests of the child are paramount and that stability and continuity in custodial arrangements are important, but it does not address or establish any rule about a “current midweek schedule” or midweek parenting time specifically. The case discusses preserving an existing satisfactory arrangement and warns against unnecessary disruption, rather than saying that a particular midweek schedule no longer serves a child’s best interests or is contrary to public policy. Thus, using Kali to support that specific proposition about a midweek schedule overstates what the case actually holds.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u2.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.” 439 Mass. at 843.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to determining custody based on the “best interests of the child,” and emphasizes that domestic violence must be considered in that assessment, but it does not articulate a broad, general rule that the best-interests standard governs all decisions relating to custody and parenting time. The cited pages focus on the need for explicit findings about the effects of domestic violence on the child within a custody determination, not on defining the overarching standard for every custody/parenting-time decision. Thus it is consistent with, but not strong authority for, the expansive formulation in the proposition.
